170952381: Assessment of Witness Credibility
The prosecution's reliance on the injured witness's testimony is justified despite the absence of certain corroborating witnesses.
Assessment of Witness Credibility
The quality of witnesses is more significant than the quantity in criminal cases.
Evaluation of Evidence
The injuries sustained by the complainant are supported by medical evidence as reflected in the Medico Legal Report.
Evaluation of Evidence
The defense's argument regarding the injuries being accidental was not substantiated.
Conviction Based on Sole Testimony
A conviction can be maintained on the sole testimony of the injured complainant when supported by credible evidence.
Conviction Based on Sole Testimony
The presence of the complainant at the scene of the incident cannot be doubted.
Consideration of Sentencing
The court considered the age and health condition of the appellants in determining the appropriateness of the sentence.
Consideration of Sentencing
The court acknowledged the time elapsed since the occurrence and the absence of prior convictions.
Granting of Compensation
Compensation was awarded to the complainant based on the injuries sustained.
Granting of Compensation
The court has the authority to impose compensation as part of the sentencing process.
Probation and Sentence Reduction
The court referenced prior case law to justify the extension of probation and reduction of sentence for the appellants.
132520342: Quashing of FIR based on compromise
There is no reasonable likelihood of the accused being convicted due to the complainant's compromise with the accused.
Quashing of FIR based on compromise
The complainant is not likely to support the prosecution.
Quashing of FIR based on compromise
It would not be in the interest of justice to decline the prayer for quashing the FIR.
Quashing of FIR based on compromise
The case does not fall within the category of exceptional cases where inherent jurisdiction should not be exercised to quash criminal proceedings.
Quashing of FIR based on compromise
Continuation of criminal proceedings would amount to abuse of process of law despite settlement and compromise.
Prolonging the litigation would not serve any useful purpose.
It is appropriate to end the criminal case to secure the ends of justice.
590433: Chief Justice's Power of Appointment
The power of appointment conferred on the Chief Justice includes the power to compulsorily retire an employee of the High Court.
Chief Justice's Power of Appointment
The interpretation of the term 'appointment' is broad and encompasses various powers including suspension, dismissal, removal, and compulsory retirement.
Existence of Applicable Rules
The High Court staff has been governed by rules related to various employment matters since 1984.
Existence of Applicable Rules
The petitioner had opted for revised pay scales under the rules, indicating the existence and application of these rules.
Adverse Confidential Reports Communication
It is not necessary to communicate every remark in the confidential rolls; only adverse remarks require communication.
Adverse Confidential Reports Communication
The purpose of communicating adverse remarks is to provide an opportunity for improvement.
Nature of Compulsory Retirement
An order of compulsory retirement is not categorized as a punishment and does not imply a stigma.
Nature of Compulsory Retirement
Compulsory retirement can be executed based on the subjective satisfaction of the authority regarding public interest.
Judicial Scrutiny of Compulsory Retirement
Judicial scrutiny is permissible if the retirement order is found to be malafide, based on no evidence, or arbitrary.
Judicial Scrutiny of Compulsory Retirement
The authority must consider the entire record of service, including both favorable and adverse entries, before deciding on compulsory retirement.
Promotion and Confidential Records
Adverse remarks prior to a promotion can be considered if the promotion was based on seniority rather than merit.
Promotion and Confidential Records
The timing of the retirement order after the petitioner reached 50 years of age does not equate to a dismissal or attach a stigma.
Publication and Knowledge of Rules
The rules governing the High Court staff have been consistently followed and known to employees since 1984.
Publication and Knowledge of Rules
The petitioner has availed himself of benefits under the relevant rules, indicating their accessibility.
1486327: Transfer of Investigation Authority
The Director General of Police has the authority to transfer cases to the Criminal Investigation Department based on complexity and nature.
Transfer of Investigation Authority
The power to transfer a case is an administrative act and does not require elaborate reasons to be recorded.
Transfer of Investigation Authority
The transfer of cases to a specific investigation agency is within the discretion of the police authority, particularly when the case involves a peculiar nature of crime.
Impartiality of Investigation
The principle that every criminal investigation must be free from political interference is paramount.
Impartiality of Investigation
Petitioner cannot dictate the investigating agency's choice; the competence to assign investigators lies with the executive.
Impartiality of Investigation
The judiciary has repeatedly emphasized the need for unbiased and transparent investigations in criminal matters.
Rights of the Complainant
The complainant has the right to seek further investigation and object to findings through judicial processes.
Rights of the Complainant
Legislative provisions exist to allow parties to challenge the conduct of an investigation or the conclusions drawn.
Rights of the Complainant
The complainant's interest in the investigation is acknowledged, but it does not extend to control over the choice of agency.
Executive Oversight in Law Enforcement
The government has the inherent right to monitor and direct law enforcement agencies.
Executive Oversight in Law Enforcement
The Chief Minister's office can engage with law enforcement to oversee cases, which does not itself imply undue influence or bias.
Executive Oversight in Law Enforcement
The administration of justice is within the purview of the state's executive power, which includes the management of police investigations.
Legal Framework Governing Investigations
The statutory framework provides for the role of various police agencies in handling specific types of crime.
Legal Framework Governing Investigations
Relevant police manuals outline the authority of the Director General of Police to assign cases to specialized units based on the crime's characteristics.
Legal Framework Governing Investigations
The classification of crimes requiring specific investigative expertise supports the assignment of cases to the appropriate agency.
1098088: Preference Criteria for Allotment
The guidelines prescribed an order of preference for the allotment of fair price shops.
Preference Criteria for Allotment
Educated unemployed were to be preferred above all other categories.
Preference Criteria for Allotment
The respondent No. 3 did not belong to any of the preferred categories.
Arbitrariness in Decision-Making
Departure from the established criteria and order of preference was not justified.
Arbitrariness in Decision-Making
The government action would be liable to be struck down if it was arbitrary and lacked rational basis.
Nature of Guidelines
Guidelines issued were administrative instructions and did not have statutory force.
Nature of Guidelines
The guidelines are meant for the guidance of authorities and cannot be ignored without valid reason.
Eligibility and Documentation
The petitioners did not provide necessary documentation to prove eligibility.
Eligibility and Documentation
Failure to furnish registration details meant the petitioner could not be considered for allotment.
Consideration of Business Experience
Additional requirements mentioned in a press-notice were not part of the established guidelines.
Consideration of Business Experience
New points raised at a later stage can violate principles of natural justice.
Requirement of Reasoning in Allotment
Authorities must provide reasons for departing from the guidelines when allotting the fair price shop.
Requirement of Reasoning in Allotment
Lack of reasoning by the authorities indicated non-application of mind.
142941226: Lack of Competence to Grant License
The appellant was not the competent authority to grant the health license, which undermines the charges of misconduct or abuse of official position.
Lack of Competence to Grant License
The competent authority was the Medical Officer of Health, who granted the permission.
The acts of the appellant were official acts, potentially qualifying for the benefit of legal protections against liability.
There was no evidence suggesting that the appellant entered into any conspiracy or received any benefit from the accused.
The appellant maintained an unblemished record of public service and complied with all conditions during the trial.
The appellants are senior citizens with health issues, which should be considered in the decision regarding suspension of sentence.
Suspension of sentence can be granted when there are no exceptional circumstances warranting its rejection, particularly when the appellant has been on bail throughout the trial.
Legal Precedent for Suspension of Sentence
Previous cases indicate that suspension of sentence is often granted liberally for fixed sentences unless exceptional circumstances are present.
The likely prolonged duration of the appeal process supports the need for suspension of the sentence to prevent the appeal from becoming infructuous.
344642: Discretion in Waiver of Interest
The Commissioner of Income-tax has the discretion to waive interest under specified conditions.
Discretion in Waiver of Interest
The exercise of discretion must be judicial and not arbitrary.
Discretion in Waiver of Interest
The discretion cannot be exercised in a whimsical or fanciful manner.
Assignment of Reasons
The assignment of reasons for a decision is a fundamental aspect of natural justice.
Assignment of Reasons
Failure to provide sufficient reasons for a decision undermines the legitimacy of the administrative authority's actions.
Conditions for Waiver
Conditions laid out for the exercise of discretion must be satisfied for a waiver of interest to be considered.
Conditions for Waiver
The relevant provisions must be interpreted harmoniously to give effect to their intent.
Jurisdiction of the High Court
The High Court retains jurisdiction to interfere in administrative decisions where discretion has not been properly exercised.
Jurisdiction of the High Court
Judicial review is available if the authority fails to address the matter properly.
Proper Exercise of Discretion
Discretion must be exercised based on relevant considerations and without undue influence from external factors.
Proper Exercise of Discretion
The authority must maintain an unbiased mind and consider objections raised by aggrieved parties.
116724952: Coextensive Liability of Borrower and Guarantor
The liability of the borrower and guarantor is coextensive, as established in relevant case law.
Coextensive Liability of Borrower and Guarantor
The action of the Bank in invoking provisions under the Act is supported by precedents regarding liability.
Scope of Judicial Interference
The principles laid down by the Apex Court define the scope of interference by the Writ Court in matters under a fiscal statute.
Scope of Judicial Interference
Interference is not warranted when alternative statutory remedies are available.
Equitable Mortgage and Collateral Security
The creation of equitable mortgage through the deposit of title deeds is a conscious act by the guarantors.
Equitable Mortgage and Collateral Security
Reaffirmation of equitable mortgage in subsequent loan agreements demonstrates the intent of the parties.
Alternative Statutory Remedy
The petitioners have an alternative statutory remedy available under the Act, which should be pursued before the Debt Recovery Tribunal.
Alternative Statutory Remedy
Judicial economy and the appropriate forum for fact and law issues favor the use of alternative remedies.
Interim Relief Consideration
The Debt Recovery Tribunal is equipped to consider interim relief requests based on the merits of the case.
Interim Relief Consideration
The timing of the e-auction necessitates prompt consideration of any appeals filed by the petitioners.
3235615: Presumption of Service of Demand Notice
If the demand notice is properly and correctly addressed, there is a presumption of service thereof.
Presumption of Service of Demand Notice
It is for the accused to prove that he did not receive the demand notice.
Burden of Proof Regarding Cheque Execution
Once the execution of the cheques is proved, the presumptions of law come into play and the initial burden of proof shifts upon the accused.
Burden of Proof Regarding Cheque Execution
These presumptions of law are rebuttable.
Standard of Proof for Rebutting Presumptions
It is not necessary for the defendant to disprove the existence of consideration by way of direct evidence.
Standard of Proof for Rebutting Presumptions
The standard of proof is preponderance of probabilities, which can be drawn from the materials on record and the circumstances relied upon.
Credibility of Evidence and Documentation
The credibility of documents presented by the accused is assessed based on their contents and the context in which they were created.
Credibility of Evidence and Documentation
Any discrepancies or lack of explanation regarding the documentation may cast doubt on its validity.
Infirmities in Complainant's Evidence
The court evaluates if there are any substantial infirmities in the complainant's evidence that may affect the presumption of liability.
Infirmities in Complainant's Evidence
The absence of proper documentation or contradictory claims may undermine the credibility of the complainant's claims.
Nature of Loan and Source of Funds
The complainant's ability to advance a loan is evaluated against the disclosed sources of funds.
Nature of Loan and Source of Funds
If the complainant fails to substantiate the source of funds, it may affect the presumption of the legitimacy of the loan.
1258703: Lack of Dishonest Intention
Dishonest intention is a principal ingredient of the offence of theft.
Lack of Dishonest Intention
There was no evidence of dishonest intention on the part of the accused in the complaint or witness statements.
Absence of Wrongful Gain or Loss
The allegations did not indicate any wrongful gain to the accused or wrongful loss to the complainant.
Absence of Wrongful Gain or Loss
The items in question were kept in the custody of the Calcutta Municipal Corporation, negating any claim of wrongful gain.
Malicious Prosecution
The prosecution was alleged to have been instituted maliciously with the intent to cause vengeance against the public servants.
Malicious Prosecution
The court noted the possibility of proceedings being maliciously instituted to obstruct lawful actions taken by the accused.
Insufficient Evidence for Prosecution
The lack of specific allegations against individual accused undermines the prosecution's case.
Insufficient Evidence for Prosecution
The absurdity and improbability of the allegations led to a conclusion that no prudent person could find sufficient grounds for prosecution.
Inherent Powers of the Court
The court has the inherent power to quash proceedings that are attended with mala fides or instituted for personal grudges.
Inherent Powers of the Court
The court must consider whether allowing the prosecution to continue serves any useful purpose or is in the interest of justice.
Obligation to Remove Obstructions
Public authorities are obligated to remove illegal encroachments on public property.
Obligation to Remove Obstructions
The legal duty of the municipal corporation includes preventing unauthorized use of public streets.
105542854: Lapse of Land Acquisition Proceedings
The Award was passed more than five years prior to the commencement of the Act of 2013.
Lapse of Land Acquisition Proceedings
Possession was not taken by following due process of law.
Lapse of Land Acquisition Proceedings
Compensation was not paid to the petitioner.
Validity of the Award
The Award was not passed within the stipulated period of two years from the date of declaration under the old Act.
Validity of the Award
Possession was never taken in accordance with law.
Acceptance of Compensation
The petitioner voluntarily accepted 50% of the compensation awarded under the old Act.
Acceptance of Compensation
The petitioner has stated his entitlement to half of the enhanced compensation.
Conduct of the Parties
The petitioner has not raised objections until after the allotment order was made.
Conduct of the Parties
The sequence of events and conduct of the petitioner would disentitle him to any relief.
Principles of Possession
Taking possession of land may vary based on whether the land is vacant or occupied.
Principles of Possession
In cases of resistance, symbolic possession may suffice if documented appropriately.
443280: The Tribunal's decision regarding the entitlement of the assessee to weighted deduction under the relevant section must align with established judicial precedents.
The binding nature of decisions from the Bombay High Court is relevant in determining the legitimacy of the Tribunal's ruling.
The jurisdiction of the High Court to entertain a reference depends on whether the assessing officer was located within its jurisdiction.
The location of the assessing authority is a decisive factor in determining which High Court has the jurisdiction to deal with a reference.
The legal implications of transferring a case from one Income-tax Officer to another must be assessed in light of relevant precedents.
The scope of further proceedings after the transfer of a case must be interpreted according to the provisions of the Act.
Every Tribunal in a State is bound by the decisions of the High Court of that State, which affects the applicability of the relevant sections of the Act.
The Appellate Tribunal operates as a single entity, and its jurisdiction is determined by the orders of the President of the Appellate Tribunal.
459021: Burden of Proof in Dishonour of Cheque Cases
The accused is required to prove by leading cogent evidence that there was no debt or liability.
Burden of Proof in Dishonour of Cheque Cases
The failure of the drawer to comply with the notice of demand constitutes the completion of the offence under the relevant section.
Effect of Payment on Criminal Liability
Payment made after the offence is committed does not absolve the accused of criminal liability.
Effect of Payment on Criminal Liability
Any payment made subsequent to the offence can only be considered in the context of sentencing, not as a defense against the criminal charge.
Modification or Alteration of Contracts
A letter which merely authorizes payment does not constitute an alteration of prior contractual obligations.
Modification or Alteration of Contracts
The absence of evidence showing that the accused acted upon the letter negates any claim of modification of the agreement.
Interpretation of Legal Notices
The purpose of issuing a legal notice is to afford the drawer an opportunity to rectify the dishonour before a complaint is filed.
Interpretation of Legal Notices
Notices cannot be construed narrowly; the substance of the notice must be examined to determine compliance.
Authority of Judicial Precedents
Statements made in judgments must be considered in the specific context of the facts of the case.
Authority of Judicial Precedents
Obiter dicta do not carry the same weight as the ratio decidendi and cannot be treated as binding precedent.
1785009: Determination of Benami Transactions
A question of benami or fraud is a mixed question of fact and law.
Determination of Benami Transactions
The legal effect of the findings of fact is a question of law that can be reviewed by the Court.
Determination of Benami Transactions
The determination of whether a transaction is benami requires the application of legal principles to the established facts.
Nature of Ownership in Joint Family Property
Self-acquired property can become joint family property if it has been voluntarily thrown into the common stock.
Nature of Ownership in Joint Family Property
The intention to abandon separate claims must be clearly established to support the conclusion that property has been incorporated into the joint family estate.
Nature of Ownership in Joint Family Property
The mere allowance of use by family members does not suffice to establish that the property has been put into common stock.
Pleading and Amendment Principles
There is no rule that limits the defendant's ability to contest an amended plaint to specific pleas without permission of the Court.
Pleading and Amendment Principles
The right to contest a claim in an amended plaint is not strictly governed by the provisions of specific sections of the law.
Pleading and Amendment Principles
The primary objective of pleadings is to clarify the points of contention between the parties.
Limitations on Appeals Concerning Findings of Fact
Findings of fact made by the trial court are generally not open to appeal unless there is a legal flaw or infirmity.
Limitations on Appeals Concerning Findings of Fact
The court does not have jurisdiction to interfere with findings of fact based on evidence even if those findings seem erroneous.
Limitations on Appeals Concerning Findings of Fact
The burden of proof lies on the party asserting that self-acquired property has been thrown into the common stock.
52562851: Sole Testimony of Eyewitness
The evidence of a sole eyewitness can be sufficient for conviction if the court finds it credible and lacking serious contradictions.
Sole Testimony of Eyewitness
There is no legal impediment to convicting a person based solely on the testimony of a single witness.
Quality of Evidence Over Quantity
The legal system emphasizes the value, weight, and quality of evidence rather than the number of witnesses.
Quality of Evidence Over Quantity
A competent court may rely on the testimony of a single credible witness while acquitting based on the lack of credibility of multiple witnesses.
Doctrine of Res Gestae
Hearsay evidence can be admissible if it forms part of the same transaction and is almost contemporaneous with the act in question.
Doctrine of Res Gestae
Statements must be made immediately after the act or event to be considered under the doctrine of res gestae.
Delay in Registration of FIR
Unexplained delay in the FIR reaching the court may lead to a presumption that it was ante-timed, which could affect the credibility of the prosecution.
Delay in Registration of FIR
The timing of the FIR registration and its dispatch to the magistrate is critical in assessing the prosecution's case.
Intent and Self-Control
The absence of a premeditated weapon suggests the absence of prior intention to kill, indicating the act was impulsive.
Intent and Self-Control
Self-control loss during a confrontation can lead to a classification of the act under lesser culpability.
1053219: Precedent on Successive Bail Applications
The court has a duty to consider the reasons and grounds on which earlier bail applications were rejected.
Precedent on Successive Bail Applications
The court must record fresh grounds that persuade it to take a different view from earlier applications.
Precedent on Successive Bail Applications
Failure to note grounds which persuaded a higher court to cancel bail is violative of binding principles.
Principle of Finality in Judicial Decisions
Once an order of bail has been confirmed by a higher court, it becomes final and should not be revisited without new circumstances.
Principle of Finality in Judicial Decisions
The court should not address points already decided in earlier applications that have become final between parties.
Requirements for Granting Bail
The court must provide cogent and satisfactory reasons for granting or rejecting anticipatory bail.
Requirements for Granting Bail
Bail should not be canceled in a mechanical manner without considering supervening circumstances.
Role of the Investigating Agency
The investigating agency has the duty to interrogate the accused, and failure to present oneself for interrogation complicates the bail application.
Role of the Investigating Agency
The court should not ignore prima facie evidence that indicates the necessity of interrogation.
Impact of FIR and Audit Reports
A well-designed FIR does not negate the possibility of involvement if evidence emerges during investigation.
Impact of FIR and Audit Reports
An audit report should not tilt the balance in favor of the accused if it does not address the specific allegations in question.
Discretion of the Court
Judicial discretion must be exercised based on facts and circumstances of each case, without bias towards the status of the accused.
Discretion of the Court
The learned judge must properly consider all evidence, including statements of witnesses, in determining bail.
78092693: The Claims Tribunal must decide applications expeditiously and based on the documents and representations provided by claimants.
The Claims Tribunal is required to verify the authenticity of the claimants' identities and assess their entitlement before issuing judgments.
The Tribunal must physically examine applicants and assess claims based on merits.
The petitioners have alternate remedies available through appeal and review under the relevant sections of the Act.
The presence of alternate remedies precludes the need for Writ Petitions unless the Tribunal lacks jurisdiction.
The petitioners failed to disclose material facts regarding pending CMAs, which undermined their claims of having no alternative remedies.
The omission of relevant facts in the Writ Petitions amounts to suppression of material fact.
The impugned order is not challenged on the grounds of the Tribunal lacking inherent jurisdiction.
Grievances regarding the compliance with statutory provisions can be addressed through available alternate remedies.
1359052: The nominee of the Registrar does not derive judicial power from the state and is not considered a 'court' within the meaning of the relevant statute.
The authority of the nominee is conferred by the Registrar and can be withdrawn, distinguishing it from the powers of a court.
The offences under the two relevant sections are distinct and may be committed with different intentions by different individuals.
There is no legislative intent to repeal the provisions of one act by the enactment of another regarding offences.
The prosecution for the offences in question does not require the prior sanction of the Registrar under the relevant act.
The authority to prosecute is not contingent upon the actions or decisions of the nominee.
186882494: Power to Allow Compounding of Non-Compoundable Offences
The High Court has the power to allow the compounding of non-compoundable offences to prevent the abuse of the process of any Court or to secure the ends of justice.
Power to Allow Compounding of Non-Compoundable Offences
This power is not confined to matrimonial disputes alone.
Inherent Power of the High Court
The inherent power of the High Court can be exercised to quash criminal proceedings when it is deemed expedient in the interest of justice.
Inherent Power of the High Court
Continuation of criminal proceedings may amount to an abuse of process of law.
The compromise between the parties was found to be voluntary and without coercion or pressure.
Impact of Compromise on Criminal Proceedings
The parties have arrived at a compromise and decided to live in peace, which indicates that no useful purpose would be served by allowing the criminal proceedings to continue.
184353058: Burden of Proof for Continuous Service
The workman is required to prove that he has been in continuous service for 240 days during the twelve months preceding the termination.
Burden of Proof for Continuous Service
It is the responsibility of the claimant to provide cogent evidence that demonstrates he worked for 240 days prior to termination.
An affidavit is insufficient proof for establishing the continuous service of 240 days; additional evidence is necessary.
The claimant must provide proof of receipt of salary or wages for 240 days or other forms of documentation to support his claim.
Error in Burden of Proof Assessment
The Labour Court and High Court erred by placing the burden of proof on the employer to demonstrate that the workman had not worked for 240 days.
Requirement of Evidence Beyond Self-Serving Statements
Self-serving statements or affidavits alone do not satisfy the burden placed on the workman to prove continuous employment for 240 days.
Requirement of Evidence Beyond Self-Serving Statements
The absence of muster rolls does not automatically lead to an adverse inference against the management.
Necessity for Claimant to Establish Workman Status
The onus is on the claimant to establish that he is a workman as defined under the relevant legal provisions.
585097: The petition lacks specific facts and details regarding the petitioner's position among unsuccessful candidates.
There is no material provided to support the assertion that scheduled caste and scheduled tribe candidates were admitted without qualifying marks.
The admission of scheduled caste and scheduled tribe candidates without minimum qualifying marks is permitted under the special provisions of the Act.
The State is allowed to make special provisions for the advancement of educationally backward classes, which includes scheduled caste and scheduled tribe candidates.
Admissions to the institution must be controlled by ordinances under the Act, and if no ordinances exist, there can be no claim of violation of such ordinances.
The purpose of reservation is to ensure access to technological institutions for scheduled caste and scheduled tribe candidates.
Different standards for filling reserved seats compared to unreserved seats are permissible, including the absence of qualifying marks.
Concessions for admission do not affect the standards required to pass final examinations, ensuring that all graduates meet necessary qualifications.
The precedents cited by the petitioner involve different factual circumstances and legal questions, and therefore do not apply to the current case.
41787046: Readiness and Willingness to Perform Contract
The plaintiff must prove continuous readiness and willingness to perform his part of the contract from the date of execution until the suit.
Readiness and Willingness to Perform Contract
Readiness refers to financial capacity, while willingness pertains to the conduct of the plaintiff wanting performance.
Readiness and Willingness to Perform Contract
The plaintiff's actions and insistence on additional documents not included in the agreement indicate a lack of readiness and willingness.
There is no presumption that time is of the essence in contracts for the sale of immovable property.
The court may infer reasonable time for performance based on express terms of the contract, nature of the property, and surrounding circumstances.
If the purchaser is unwilling to make payment without fulfillment of additional conditions, they are not entitled to specific performance.
Specific performance cannot be enforced in favor of a person who has not proven their readiness and willingness to perform essential contract terms.
The plaintiff must allege and prove continuous readiness and willingness to perform the contract.
117514014: The petitioners provided sufficient documentary evidence to establish their relationship with the deceased.
No other claims were made regarding legal heirs, establishing the petitioners as the only surviving legal heirs.
The driving of the truck was characterized as rash and negligent, resulting in the fatal accident.
The concept of res ipsa loquitur applies, signifying that the accident itself implies negligence.
Compensation should be assessed based on the minimum wages applicable to the deceased's educational qualifications.
The multiplier method for calculating loss of dependency was applied in accordance with established precedent.
The burden of proof falls on the insurance company to demonstrate that the insured was aware of any breach of policy conditions.
Holding more than one driving license is prohibited under the law, but the insurance company must prove knowledge on the part of the insured for liability to be negated.
Certificates issued by the Regional Transport Authority are public documents and require no additional proof.
129210074: The judgment in Narinder Singh and others vs. [ENTITY] and another establishes that certain offences under [ACT] cannot be compounded.

The Hon'ble Supreme Court in Gian Singh v. [ENTITY] has discussed the inherent powers of the High Court to quash criminal proceedings where the parties have entered into a compromise, except for serious offences.
Impact of Compromise on Criminal Proceedings
Continuation of criminal proceedings between the parties would be an abuse of the process of law.
Impact of Compromise on Criminal Proceedings
The present compromise is considered beneficial for the parties and aims to bring peace and harmony between them.
55350976: Right to be searched before a Gazetted Officer or Magistrate
The requirement under the relevant section of the Act mandates that an accused must be informed of his right to be searched in the presence of a Gazetted Officer or a Magistrate.
Right to be searched before a Gazetted Officer or Magistrate
Failure to adequately communicate this right may invalidate the recovery of contraband and, consequently, the conviction.
The prosecution's obligation to inform the accused of his right under the relevant section of the Act is considered a mandatory requirement that must be strictly adhered to.
Non-compliance with this provision can lead to the recovery of contraband being deemed suspect and the conviction potentially being unsustainable.
The interpretation of 'search of a person' under the relevant section of the Act is limited to the physical person and does not extend to items being carried by the individual.
If the contraband is recovered from an item not inextricably connected to the person, the provisions of the section may not apply.
The considerable quantity of contraband recovered suggests that it is unlikely to have been planted, which supports the prosecution's evidence.

The statutory provisions specify that bail for offenses involving commercial quantities of contraband can only be granted if there are reasonable grounds for believing the accused is not guilty and is not likely to commit further offenses while on bail.
The period of incarceration and the severity of the sentence are factors that also influence the decision on bail.
1749801: The investigator complied with the mandatory provisions of the Act by sending a notice to a superior officer about the information received.
The appellants were duly informed of their right to be searched before a Gazetted Officer or a Magistrate.
Mere delay in sending samples for chemical analysis is not fatal to the prosecution case if the samples were kept in proper custody.
The integrity of the sample was maintained as evidenced by the seals being intact upon arrival at the laboratory.
The absence of independent witnesses does not inherently invalidate the prosecution's case when the recovery occurs in a public place.
The testimony of police officers can be relied upon as valid evidence despite the lack of independent corroboration.
It is not a requirement of law that all documentation must be completed at the spot of recovery; procedural guidelines are advisory in nature.
Failure to prepare the CFSL form at the spot does not necessarily undermine the legitimacy of the recovery.
1734912: The Tribunal found that the driver of the jeep was not at fault in the accident.
The High Court did not provide sufficient reasons for reversing the Tribunal's finding regarding the liability of the insurance company.
The question of negligence was a factual determination that required clear evidence, which the High Court failed to establish.
The insurance company cannot be held liable simply because the truck was uninsured.
A gratuitous passenger in a goods carriage is not covered by the insurance policy according to established precedents.
The insurance contract was specifically for third party risks and did not extend to cover the risks of passengers like the deceased.
The deceased was not the driver of the vehicle, thus excluding coverage under the terms of the insurance policy.
Principles of Social Justice and Insurance Law
The provisions of the relevant Act are designed to enforce social justice but are specifically confined to third party risks.
Principles of Social Justice and Insurance Law
Insurance policies, being contracts, should be interpreted according to their specific terms and should not extend beyond what is expressly covered.
183937224: Presumption of Company's Inability to Pay Debt
It is not sufficient to show merely that a company has omitted to pay a debt due despite service of notice; it must be shown that the company omitted to pay without reasonable excuse.
Presumption of Company's Inability to Pay Debt
The machinery for winding up will not be utilized merely as a means for realizing debts due from a company.
Presumption of Company's Inability to Pay Debt
Merely because a reply to a statutory notice is not given, it cannot be said that the debt is either admitted or that a presumption can be drawn that the respondent is unable to pay the debt.
Bonafide Dispute and Substantial Defense
If the debt is bonafide disputed and the defense is substantial, the court will not wind up the company.
Bonafide Dispute and Substantial Defense
Winding up orders cannot be passed on mere asking; substantial defense must be present.
Bonafide Dispute and Substantial Defense
The court must decide whether the grounds of dispute are substantial and not merely a camouflage or smoke screen.
Arbitration Clause as an Appropriate Remedy
When there is a mutually agreed arbitration clause, the company proceedings are not an appropriate remedy.
Arbitration Clause as an Appropriate Remedy
A winding up petition should not be admitted when the defense raised is substantial and the claim can be subject to arbitration.
Crystallization of Debt
A creditor seeking winding up must prove that the debt is clear and unimpeachable in law; the debt must have crystallized.
Crystallization of Debt
If accounts are not settled, the debt cannot be said to have crystallized.
11279: Reliability of Testimony from Close Relatives
A close relative who is a natural witness cannot be regarded as an 'interested witness'.
Reliability of Testimony from Close Relatives
Relationship by itself is not a ground to discredit the testimony of a witness if it is otherwise found to be consistent and true.
Evaluation of Interested Witness Testimony
Evidence of interested witnesses cannot be discarded on the sole ground of interestedness.
Evaluation of Interested Witness Testimony
Witness testimony should be subjected to close scrutiny, but interested witnesses are not necessarily false witnesses.
Acceptance of Testimony of Solitary Witness
A Court can act on the testimony of a single witness if the evidence is trustworthy.
Acceptance of Testimony of Solitary Witness
Corroboration is not a rule of law but one of caution; thus, conviction can be based on the testimony of a solitary witness if reliable.
Implications of Delayed Reporting
Delay in lodging a report may not be fatal to the prosecution when the incident is well established by medical evidence.
Implications of Delayed Reporting
In cases of family disputes, delay could be due to anxiety in saving the victim's life and not necessarily indicative of a false report.
Leniency in Sentencing
A lenient view in sentencing may already have been taken by the trial judge, and further leniency is not warranted merely because of familial relationships.
Leniency in Sentencing
Long pendency of a matter does not justify a lesser sentence for the accused.
57681929: Nature of Judicial Discretion
The court must ensure that the executive function of the Public Prosecutor has not been improperly exercised.
Nature of Judicial Discretion
The court is required to check that the withdrawal of prosecution is not an attempt to interfere with the normal course of justice for illegitimate reasons.
Criteria for Withdrawal of Prosecution
The withdrawal from prosecution must be sought only for furthering the cause of public justice.
Criteria for Withdrawal of Prosecution
The application for withdrawal must be made after independent consideration by the Public Prosecutor.
Public Interest Consideration
The court must verify that the decision to withdraw serves public interest and does not thwart or stifle the process of law.
Public Interest Consideration
The court must ensure that the Public Prosecutor's discretion is not influenced by irrelevant and extraneous considerations.
Assessment of Evidence
The court must determine whether the application for withdrawal is based on sufficient evidence and good faith.
Assessment of Evidence
The prosecution cannot withdraw based solely on a perceived lack of evidence without proper justification.
Impact on Public Confidence
Granting consent for withdrawal may undermine public confidence in the rule of law.
Impact on Public Confidence
Withdrawal of prosecution is likely to result in adverse consequences affecting public peace.
16802923: Compromise as a Means of Justice
The compromise is essential for harmony and orderly behavior in modern society.
Compromise as a Means of Justice
The power to enhance a compromise contributes to social amity and reduces friction.
Compromise as a Means of Justice
Compromise should be accepted in disputes that arise from various contexts, not limited to matrimonial discord.
There is no statutory bar under the applicable act that limits the inherent power of the court to quash proceedings.
The court has the authority to quash even non-compoundable offenses to prevent abuse of law and secure justice.
In disputes of a purely personal nature, the court should accept the terms of compromise in criminal proceedings.
Maintaining cases with no possibility of a favorable outcome for the prosecution is an inefficient use of judicial resources.
The court can exercise its inherent powers to quash FIRs when a compromise has been reached between the parties.
58962835: The approach of the civil court should be to determine whether its jurisdiction has been ousted by a special statute rather than whether it retains jurisdiction.
General law should yield to special law, as established in precedents.
Once an application compliant with arbitration provisions is filed, the civil court is bound to refer the dispute to arbitration as per the mandatory language of the Act.
The determination of whether the arbitration clause applies to the dispute should be made by the Arbitrator.
The Arbitrator has the jurisdiction to decide on his own jurisdiction and the validity of the arbitration agreement.
Contentious issues should not be resolved at the appointment stage of the arbitrator; such matters should be raised before the arbitral tribunal.
The Act provides for a complete code for adjudication and encourages alternative dispute resolution mechanisms such as arbitration.
The existence of an arbitration clause implies that the civil court's jurisdiction is barred.
The provisions of the Act may not apply if specifically exempted in the agreement, as noted in the parties' understanding.
702752: Right to Freedom of Speech and Expression
The petitioners assert a fundamental right to interview condemned prisoners as part of freedom of speech and expression.
Right to Freedom of Speech and Expression
Restrictions on freedom of speech must be justified under specified grounds.
Right to Freedom of Speech and Expression
Freedom of speech and expression includes the right to publish and circulate one's ideas and opinions through various media.
Reasonable Restrictions on Fundamental Rights
Restrictions on fundamental rights must be reasonable and cannot be arbitrary.
Reasonable Restrictions on Fundamental Rights
Any denial of rights must be supported by valid reasons that align with the limitations specified under the law.
Equality Before Law
All citizens, including condemned prisoners, retain their rights under the law, and should be treated equally in terms of access to express their views.
Public Interest and Social Control
Interviews and videography should not be restricted unless they pose a threat to public order or the security of the state.
Public Interest and Social Control
The role of the press and media in a democratic society is essential for informing the public.
Judicial Oversight of Executive Action
The court has the duty to ensure that restrictions imposed by the executive on fundamental rights are justified and reasonable.
Consent of Interviewees
The willingness of condemned prisoners to be interviewed is a significant factor in determining the legality of the request.
Legal Precedents Supporting Interview Rights
Previous court rulings have established that condemned prisoners maintain certain rights, including the right to be interviewed.
30395287: Consideration of Age and Time Lapse
The age of the petitioner, being about 70 years, is a relevant factor in determining the appropriateness of the sentence.
Consideration of Age and Time Lapse
The significant time lapse of approximately 23 years since the commission of the offence is a consideration for reducing the sentence.
There exists judicial precedent allowing for the reduction of sentences below the minimum prescribed period under the relevant Act in peculiar circumstances.
The court has the authority to take into account the individual circumstances of the accused when determining an appropriate sentence.
The health condition of the petitioner, which includes suffering from medical ailments, is a factor that can influence the sentence.
The familial responsibilities of the petitioner, including the dependence of ailing family members, warrant consideration in the sentencing decision.
The lack of previous criminal records or antecedents of the petitioner is relevant to the sentencing evaluation.
15067133: Jurisdiction and Competence of Courts
The designation of the seat of arbitration does not confer exclusive jurisdiction on the Court of that location.
Jurisdiction and Competence of Courts
The Court where the cause of action arises may have jurisdiction even if the seat of arbitration is designated elsewhere.
Jurisdiction and Competence of Courts
The principle of concurrent jurisdiction applies where both the seat of arbitration and the location of the cause of action are within India.
Waiver of Jurisdictional Objection
A party not objecting to the jurisdiction of a court may be seen as having waived such an objection.
Waiver of Jurisdictional Objection
The conduct of a party in prior proceedings may affect their ability to raise jurisdictional issues later.
Effect of Previous Applications
The first application made under a particular section must be capable of being granted for the bar on subsequent applications to apply.
Effect of Previous Applications
A Court's lack of subject matter jurisdiction on a prior application can affect its ability to enforce the bar under a specific section.
Nature of Relief under the Act
Only specific types of applications are permitted under the relevant section of the Act.
Nature of Relief under the Act
Prayers in a petition must be capable of being granted; otherwise, the petition may not be maintainable.
Comity of Jurisdiction
The principle of comity of jurisdiction may apply where one court has yet to decide on its jurisdiction but has been approached first.
Comity of Jurisdiction
A court should respect the determinations of another court unless the latter is yet to decide on its jurisdiction.
Implications of Award and Subsequent Petitions
The passing of an arbitral award may render certain prayers in related petitions academic or infructuous.
Implications of Award and Subsequent Petitions
A petition challenging an award must be filed in the correct jurisdiction and within the appropriate time frame.
98180972: Delay in Lodging FIR
Delay in lodging an FIR in cases of sexual offences is not necessarily material and can occur due to various reasons, including the reluctance of the victim or her family.
Delay in Lodging FIR
The courts have consistently held that the trauma, fear of social stigma, and the psychological state of the victim can justify delays in reporting such incidents.
Victim's Age Assessment
The assessment of the victim's age, including medical and radiological reports, plays a crucial role in determining consent in cases of alleged sexual offences.
Victim's Age Assessment
If evidence supports that the victim was above the age of consent, it significantly impacts the validity of the charges against the accused.
Evidentiary Value of Victim's Testimony
The testimony of the prosecutrix is to be placed on a higher pedestal than that of an ordinary witness, but it must still withstand judicial scrutiny.
Evidentiary Value of Victim's Testimony

While the testimony of the victim commands great weight, it is subject to examination for consistency and reliability, and cannot be accepted automatically without corroboration in questionable circumstances.
Burden of Proof on the Defence
When the defence claims the victim was a consenting party, the burden lies on the defence to provide evidence to support this claim.
Burden of Proof on the Defence
The court must assess the evidence presented to determine whether the prosecution has met its burden of proof beyond a reasonable doubt.
Conduct of the Victim
The conduct of the victim during and after the alleged incident can be indicative of whether the incident was one of abduction or mutual consent.
Conduct of the Victim
If the victim had opportunities to escape or raise alarm but did not do so, it raises questions about the credibility of the prosecution's case.
Principles Regarding Corroboration

In cases of sexual offences, a lack of corroboration does not automatically negate the victim's testimony, but the absence of corroborative evidence can be significant if the victim's account is inconsistent or lacks believability.
Principles Regarding Corroboration
The court must balance the need to protect the rights of the accused against the testimony of the victim, ensuring that the conviction is supported by satisfactory evidence.
Appellate Court's Role
The appellate court must provide clear reasoning for accepting or rejecting the evidence presented in the lower court.
Appellate Court's Role
The assessment of evidence by the trial court must be critically analyzed to ensure that the decision to convict or acquit is based on a proper understanding of the facts.
357949: Adventure in the Nature of Trade
The determination of whether a transaction constitutes an adventure in the nature of trade is a mixed question of law and fact.
Adventure in the Nature of Trade
A single transaction can be classified as business under the definition of 'business' in relevant statutes.
Adventure in the Nature of Trade
The mere intention to profit from a transaction does not automatically classify it as an adventure in the nature of trade.
Adventure in the Nature of Trade
The character and circumstances of the venture must be considered to assess whether it constitutes trade.
Adventure in the Nature of Trade
The presumption that a transaction is an adventure in the nature of trade can be rebutted by evidence showing that the purchase was for capital accretion instead.
Adventure in the Nature of Trade
An isolated transaction may not be treated as an adventure in the nature of trade if it was not intended for resale but rather for compensation.
Adventure in the Nature of Trade
The burden of proof lies on the department to establish that a transaction is an adventure in the nature of trade.
Legal Principles Relating to Capital Gains
Profit arising from a transaction must be assessed based on the intention of the purchaser at the time of acquisition.
Legal Principles Relating to Capital Gains
An isolated purchase without the intent to sell at a profit indicates capital accretion rather than income from business.
Legal Principles Relating to Capital Gains
The expectations of compensation based on market value at the time of notification are relevant in determining the nature of the purchase.
2818464: Credibility of Discovery Evidence

The essence of the proof of a discovery under the relevant section is that it should be credibly proved that the discovery made was relevant and material and proceeded in pursuance of information supplied by the accused in custody.
Credibility of Discovery Evidence

If the court finds that the fact of information having been given by the accused in custody is credible and acceptable, even in the absence of a recorded statement, the discovery will not suffer from any vice and can be acted upon.
Requirements for Admissibility of Discovery
The fact of which evidence is sought must be relevant to the issue, and the discovery must have been in consequence of some information received from the accused and not by the accused's own act.
Requirements for Admissibility of Discovery
The discovery of fact in consequence of information received from an accused in custody must be deposed to.
Legal Principles on Recovery Evidence
The doctrine of confirmation by subsequent events suggests that if any fact is discovered based on information obtained from a prisoner, such discovery is reliable.
Legal Principles on Recovery Evidence
The absence of independent witnesses does not render the recovery inadmissible, and police officials are considered competent witnesses.
Possession and Ownership in Theft Cases
A complainant may be any person who has information of the offence and can bring law into motion without needing to be the owner of the stolen article.
Possession and Ownership in Theft Cases
De-facto possession of the stolen article with the complainant is sufficient to consider possession over articles, even if the de-jure owner is someone else.
Implications of Double Jeopardy
A person once tried by a competent court for an offence and convicted or acquitted cannot be tried again for the same offence on the same facts.
Implications of Double Jeopardy
The law does not prevent a person from being held liable for separate offences committed, even if they are of a similar nature.
Assessment of Witness Credibility
Minor discrepancies in witness testimonies do not necessarily undermine their reliability, especially if they do not affect the core of the prosecution's case.
Assessment of Witness Credibility
Only contradictions that affect the root of the dispute are material and can lead to rejection of evidence.
113907644: The execution of a recovery certificate should not be contingent upon disputes pending in a Co-operative Court.
The provisions of the relevant sections in the Act are separate and distinct, providing different remedies.
The intention of the legislature was to provide a speedy remedy for the recovery of amounts due from defaulting members.
The opening words of the relevant section give it an overriding effect over other provisions.
The finality attached to the certificate granted by the Registrar under the relevant section is paramount.
The principle of 'clean hands' does not bar a party from seeking relief if they have not previously addressed the same issue in prior proceedings.
Filing disputes in the Co-operative Court while recovery proceedings are ongoing is seen as an attempt to stall the recovery process.
68770218: The Claims Tribunal determined the status of the deceased as the owner of the goods, impacting the liability of the Insurance Company.
The legal principle established that the risk of the owner of the goods or their representative is covered only if they travel in the cabin of the vehicle.
The Claims Tribunal found that the driver was not competent to drive a commercial vehicle, leading to a breach of the insurance policy terms.
The statutory liability of the insurer to compensate third parties is established even in cases of breach, allowing for recovery rights against the insured.
The calculation of compensation is based on the preponderance of probabilities, rather than the necessity of documentary evidence for deceased's income.
Legal precedent dictates specific guidelines for calculating future prospects and inflation adjustments in compensation.
131003910: The Investigating Officer was required to reduce secret information into writing prior to the apprehension of the accused.
Applicability of Provisions of the Act
The provisions of the Act concerning recovery are applicable only in specific circumstances involving enclosed places, not public places.
Applicability of Provisions of the Act
The definition of 'public place' in the context of the Act includes locations accessible to the public.
The presence of a Gazetted Officer during the search and recovery suffices the legal requirements under the Act.
The Investigating Officer's immediate superior, a Gazetted Officer, was present at the time of search and recovery.
The lack of independent witness testimony does not fatally undermine the prosecution's case, provided the quality of evidence is sufficient.
The reluctance of witnesses to testify is acknowledged and does not invalidate the prosecution's evidence.
A natural presumption arises regarding the possession of narcotics when evidence establishes recovery from the accused's conscious possession.
91134679: Prosecution for Perjury
Prosecution for perjury should not be initiated too readily and should be based on conclusive evidence rather than inconclusive and doubtful material.
Prosecution for Perjury
A prima facie case of deliberate falsehood must be established before prosecution is considered expedient in the interest of justice.
Nature of Evidence Required
A statement must be compared with unimpeachable evidence to determine its falsity.
Nature of Evidence Required
Merely contradicting statements made by parties does not suffice to establish perjury without distinct evidence of commission of an offence.
Judicial Discretion in Initiating Proceedings
Courts should exercise caution in initiating proceedings for perjury and should do so in exceptional circumstances only.
Judicial Discretion in Initiating Proceedings
There must be grounds of a nature higher than mere surmise or suspicion for initiating such proceedings.
Dependency on Thorough Investigation
A thorough investigation or detailed inquiry is necessary to substantiate claims of perjury before proceeding with prosecution.
Dependency on Thorough Investigation
Investigative reports must be substantial and not preliminary in nature to be considered as evidence in perjury cases.
Context of Judicial Orders
The context in which judicial orders are made must be considered, especially if prior orders have been based on different grounds.
Context of Judicial Orders
The existence of prior judicial decisions or orders related to the matter affects the assessment of new claims of perjury.
919364: Jurisdiction of the Government to take suo motu revision
The Government has the authority to examine records of any order passed under the Act.
Jurisdiction of the Government to take suo motu revision
The phrase 'against which no appeal has been preferred' indicates the scope of the Government's revisional powers.
Jurisdiction of the Government to take suo motu revision
The Government's revisional powers are not limited to appealable orders alone.
Jurisdiction of the Government to take suo motu revision
The Act seeks to achieve equitable distribution of land and prevent concentration of land ownership.
Implied powers of the Government under the Act
The power to issue interim orders is essential for the effective execution of the Act.
Implied powers of the Government under the Act
The existence of power to issue interim orders is implied for the purpose of maintaining status quo during the proceedings.
Implied powers of the Government under the Act
If the Government cannot issue interim orders, the functioning of the Act could be undermined.
Reasonableness of delay in exercising revisional powers
No specific period of limitation is prescribed for the exercise of revisional powers.
Reasonableness of delay in exercising revisional powers
The reasonable time for revisional powers should be determined by the facts and nature of the order being revised.
Reasonableness of delay in exercising revisional powers
The Government's responsibility to ensure compliance with the Act supersedes individual delays.
Nature of partnership and property rights
The property of a partnership firm is owned by the firm itself and not by individual partners.
Nature of partnership and property rights
Partners do not hold property as co-owners; the firm is treated as a legal entity for property ownership.
Nature of partnership and property rights
Legal precedents clarify that the rights of partners in a firm differ from those of co-owners.
Social purpose underlying the Act
The Act aims to prevent speculation and profiteering in urban land.
Social purpose underlying the Act
The ultimate goal is to achieve equitable distribution of land to serve the common good.
Social purpose underlying the Act
The provisions of the Act reflect a legislative intent to regulate land use for social welfare.
74665339: Cause of Action and Limitation
A cause of action must include some act done by the defendant, which is necessary for the plaintiff to prove in order to obtain a decree.
Cause of Action and Limitation
The suit may be dismissed when no cause of action is disclosed or when it is barred by limitation.
Cause of Action and Limitation
The petitioners contended that the suit was barred by limitation since the cause of action arose in 1976, while the suit was filed in 2015.
Application of Hindu Mitakshara Law
Hindu Mitakshara law can only be applied to individuals who are Hindus.
Application of Hindu Mitakshara Law
The petitioners, being Christians, cannot be bound by Hindu Mitakshara law.
Ownership and Title
Entries in the Jamabandi are not proof of title; they are only statements for revenue purposes.
Ownership and Title
The burden to prove title lies with the plaintiff, and entries in revenue records are insufficient to establish ownership.
Rejection of the Plaint
The trial court must ascertain whether a real cause of action has been set out in the plaint.
Rejection of the Plaint
If the plaint is manifestly vexatious and meritless, it should be rejected at the first hearing.
Right to Trial
When questions of fact and law are involved, the dispute can only be decided through a trial.
Right to Trial
Dismissing the suit at an early stage without trial risks miscarriage of justice.
17233281: Presumptions regarding consideration for Negotiable Instruments
The provisions of the Act create a presumption that every negotiable instrument was made for consideration.
Presumptions regarding consideration for Negotiable Instruments
It is presumed that the holder of a cheque received it for the discharge of any debt or liability.
The evidential burden lies on the defence to prove that the cheque was not received toward the discharge of any liability.
The statutory presumptions require the accused to bring forth evidence to rebut them.
Standard of proof in criminal cases
The standard of proof for the prosecution is beyond reasonable doubt, while the accused only needs to prove their defence on a preponderance of probabilities.
Specific allegations must be made against directors to establish their responsibility for the company’s conduct.
Clear and unambiguous allegations are necessary for holding directors liable under the Act.
The credibility of the complainant must be established, and contradictions in testimony can undermine the case.
The complainant must provide evidence for claims of loan advancements and repayment assurances.
7798707: Non-joining of Independent Witnesses
The failure to join independent witnesses in the investigation raises significant doubts about the prosecution's case.
Non-joining of Independent Witnesses
The absence of independent witnesses, despite their availability, is considered a serious infirmity in the prosecution case.
Non-joining of Independent Witnesses
The police's explanation for not joining independent witnesses is deemed an afterthought and is liable to be rejected.
Credibility of Evidence
The unexplained omission to examine independent witnesses assumes significance when the evidence of eyewitnesses raises doubts about their presence at the time of the occurrence.
Credibility of Evidence
The lack of efforts made by police to contact public witnesses undermines the weight of the police officers' testimony, even if it does not affect its admissibility.
Procedural Obligations of Investigating Officers
It is obligatory for the investigating officer to seek assistance from independent witnesses to authenticate the investigation.
Procedural Obligations of Investigating Officers
The absence of independent witnesses at a public place during a significant event, without reasonable explanation, affects the credibility of the investigation.
Benefit of Doubt
In cases where non-joining of independent witnesses is established, the accused is entitled to the benefit of doubt.
Benefit of Doubt
The prosecution's failure to prove its case beyond reasonable doubt leads to the acquittal of the accused.
Inconsistencies in Testimony
Discrepancies regarding the timing of the FIR registration and the preparation of the seizure memo erode the credibility of the prosecution's witnesses.
Inconsistencies in Testimony
Inconsistencies in the testimonies of prosecution witnesses necessitate careful scrutiny of the prosecution's case.
76135044: Credibility of Police Testimony
The testimony of police personnel should be treated in the same manner as testimony of any other witness.
Credibility of Police Testimony
There is no principle of law that without corroboration by independent witnesses their testimony cannot be relied upon.
Credibility of Police Testimony
The presumption that a person acts honestly applies as much in favour of police personnel as of other persons.
Irregularities in Search and Seizure
Irregularity in a search cannot vitiate the seizure of the articles.
Irregularities in Search and Seizure
Failure to comply with statutory provisions in search and seizure is not invariably fatal for the prosecution's case.
Irregularities in Search and Seizure
If reliable local witnesses are not available, the search would not be vitiated.
Requirement of Independent Witnesses
The search before an independent witness imparts much more authenticity and creditworthiness to the search and seizure proceedings.
Requirement of Independent Witnesses
The prosecution must offer a satisfactory explanation for not associating independent witnesses.
Requirement of Independent Witnesses
The absence of independent witnesses requires careful scrutiny of the evidence provided by official witnesses.
Assessment of Evidence
The unrebutted testimony of the police officials and other material on record can establish charges against the accused.
Assessment of Evidence
Minor contradictions in testimony are common in criminal matters and do not necessarily undermine the prosecution's case.
Assessment of Evidence
The court must evaluate the credibility and coherence of official witnesses' testimony with extra caution.
227510: Propriety of Enquiry
The legality and propriety of the disciplinary enquiry were upheld by the Labour Court.
Propriety of Enquiry
The findings of the enquiry were based on adequate evidence that withstood cross-examination.
Insufficient Evidence
The petitioner argued that the evidence regarding the misconduct was insufficient or contradictory.
Insufficient Evidence
The Labour Court's finding of inadequate proof for one of the charges was recognized.
Judicial Intervention
The case was argued as deserving judicial intervention due to perceived disproportion in punishment.
Judicial Intervention
The concept of judicial review under the relevant section of the Act allows for examination of the appropriateness of punishment.
Disciplinary Authority's Role
The Disciplinary Authority is the sole judge of facts in departmental proceedings.
Disciplinary Authority's Role
The Appellate Authority has jurisdiction to re-appreciate evidence and come to its own conclusions regarding facts.
Standard of Misconduct
The Court acknowledged the necessity to maintain a standard of behavior expected from a driver.
Standard of Misconduct
Misconduct must be assessed in the context of the duties performed and the trust placed in the employee.
Discretion of Employers
Employers retain discretion to determine appropriate disciplinary actions in cases of serious misconduct.
Discretion of Employers
The Labour Court should not substitute the penalty imposed by the employer in such cases.
Gravity of Misconduct
The proved acts of insubordination and damage to work were significant enough to justify the dismissal.
Gravity of Misconduct
The punishment must reflect the severity of the misconduct to maintain workplace discipline.
Limits of Judicial Review
Judicial review does not extend to correcting all perceived wrong decisions; it is limited to serious violations of law.
Limits of Judicial Review
The High Court should not interfere unless findings are based on no evidence or are wholly perverse.
963927: The determination of whether the income received by the assessees constitutes salary or business income is essential for correct tax assessment.
The distinction between employees and agents impacts the classification of income under relevant sections of the tax law.
The Income-tax Officer must have reason to believe that there was an omission or failure by the assessees to disclose material facts necessary for assessment.
The obligation to disclose material facts does not extend beyond the primary facts that are fully and truly disclosed to the assessing authority.
The powers and duties outlined in the articles of association influence the categorization of assessees as agents rather than employees.
The level of control exercised by the board of directors is a factor in determining the relationship between the assessees and the company.
Previous court decisions establish the principle that managing directors can be classified as agents based on their powers and the nature of their roles.
The distinction between an agent and a servant is critical in determining the nature of the relationship and the corresponding tax obligations.
94171194: Delay and Laches
The law of limitation is essential for the general welfare and should be enforced even if it appears harsh.
Delay and Laches
Courts have no power to extend the period of limitation on equitable grounds.
Delay and Laches
Lack of bona fides in seeking condonation of delay is a significant factor.
Delay and Laches
The conduct and behavior of a party concerning inaction or negligence are relevant in assessing delay.
Delay and Laches
Delay should not be perceived as a non-serious matter, and the courts must draw a distinction between delay and inordinate delay.
Principles Governing Condonation of Delay
Sufficient cause is a prerequisite for the court's discretion to condone delay.
Principles Governing Condonation of Delay
Mandatory provisions must be complied with, and unexplained delays cannot be condoned on sympathetic grounds.
Principles Governing Condonation of Delay
A party cannot take advantage of others' diligent actions by approaching the court belatedly.
Principles Governing Condonation of Delay
The courts should not adopt an injustice-oriented approach when considering applications for condonation of delay.
Implications of Delay in Writ Petitions
Delay or laches must be considered by the courts when exercising discretionary powers.
Implications of Delay in Writ Petitions
In cases of belated approaches, writ petitions are typically dismissed due to unexplained delays.
Implications of Delay in Writ Petitions
The principles of limitation are applicable in writ jurisdiction despite the specific statutes not applying.
71732168: Equity in Recovery of Excess Payments
Recovery of excess payments should consider the equity and hardship caused to employees.
Equity in Recovery of Excess Payments
Courts disallow recovery of excess amounts paid to employees based on the principle of equity.
Equity in Recovery of Excess Payments
Employees who receive excess payments due to no fault of their own should not be subjected to recovery, especially after a significant period.
Judicial Discretion in Recovery Matters
Judicial discretion must be exercised in cases of recovery to avoid undue hardship to employees.
Judicial Discretion in Recovery Matters
Recovery should not be ordered if it is proven that the employee had no knowledge of receiving excess payments.
Judicial Discretion in Recovery Matters
If the error in payment is detected after a long duration, recovery may be deemed iniquitous or arbitrary.
Time Frame for Recovery Enforcement
Recoveries sought more than five years after the erroneous payment is considered arbitrary and iniquitous.
Time Frame for Recovery Enforcement
Recovery actions undertaken shortly after the erroneous payment may be permissible unless undue hardship is demonstrated.
Impact on Employees Close to Retirement
Recovery efforts against employees who are nearing retirement or have retired are particularly harsh and should be avoided.
Impact on Employees Close to Retirement
Financial burdens placed on employees close to retirement due to recovery actions can outweigh any benefits to the employer.
24745928: Establishment of Negligence
The petitioners must prove that the vehicle was driven rashly and negligently to succeed in their claim.
Establishment of Negligence
The evidence presented, including police investigation results, suggested negligence on the part of the driver.
Establishment of Negligence
Holistic view and preponderance of probability are applicable in establishing negligence in road accident cases.
Standards of Proof in Compensation Claims
Strict proof beyond reasonable doubt is not required in compensation claims under the relevant Act.
Standards of Proof in Compensation Claims
A holistic approach is necessary to evaluate the evidence in compensation petitions.
Evidence of Negligence
Documentation such as FIR, charge sheets, and police investigation records can serve as sufficient proof of negligence.
Evidence of Negligence
An adverse inference can be drawn if the driver does not appear in court to support their defense.
Determination of Compensation
The compensation must aim to restore the petitioner to the position prior to the accident as much as possible.
Determination of Compensation
Compensation in injury cases is categorized into pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages, each with specific sub-heads.
Determination of Compensation
Future loss of income and medical expenses should be accounted for when determining compensation.
Liability of Insurers
Insurers may be relieved of liability if the driver lacks a valid driving license or the vehicle lacks a valid permit.
Liability of Insurers
Legal precedents guide the determination of liability and recovery rights for insurers.
443172: The High Court misapplied the precedent related to a judicial officer to a case involving a temporary government servant.
Judicial precedents must be considered in the context of the specific protections and circumstances applicable to the parties involved.
Nature of Termination of Temporary Government Servants
The power of the Government to terminate a temporary government servant's employment without an enquiry is upheld as lawful under the applicable rules.
Nature of Termination of Temporary Government Servants
Termination simpliciter does not constitute a penalty and can be executed without the requirement of a misconduct enquiry.
An enquiry into alleged misconduct must be pursued to a logical conclusion to avoid rendering the termination illegal.
If an enquiry into misconduct is abandoned, the subsequent termination may be considered unlawful.
Despite the incorrect application of law by the High Court, the discretionary power allows for upholding the respondent's reinstatement based on the duration of service prior to termination.
164909679: The judgment of acquittal should only be interfered with when there are compelling and substantial reasons to do so.
An appellate court should refrain from interfering with an order of acquittal if the trial court has taken a plausible view of the evidence.
The trial court's conclusion that there was no evidence connecting the accused to the alleged crime was reasonable.
The presence of key witnesses was doubted as their statements did not support the prosecution case.
If the trial court has disbelieved eyewitness testimony based on the naturalness of their conduct, it indicates proper exercise of discretion in evaluating evidence.
The appellate court respects the trial court's assessment of evidence unless it is shown that relevant and convincing materials have been unjustifiably eliminated.
960471: Inconsistencies were found between two decisions of three-Judge Benches and the decision of a nine-Judge Bench.
The question of whether a claim for refund after final assessment is governed by a specific section of the Act was referred to a larger Bench.
The applicability of the doctrine of unjust enrichment in the context of refund claims was a key issue.
The difference between provisional assessment of duty and payment of duty under protest was highlighted.
Whether a purchaser is entitled to claim refund based on payments made under protest or provisional assessment was discussed.
The relevance of filing an independent application for refund after final assessment was evaluated.
Requirement of Evidence for Refund Claims
The necessity for a claimant to provide evidence that the incidence of duty has not been passed on to others was emphasized.
Distinction Between Manufacturer and Purchaser Claims
The distinction between the rights of a manufacturer to claim refund and that of a purchaser was clarified.
The court's consideration of concurrent findings of fact from lower authorities in evaluating the claim for refund.
49999233: Authority of High Court to Cancel Bail
The High Court has the power to cancel bail granted by the Sessions Court as it is a superior court in the hierarchy of courts.
Authority of High Court to Cancel Bail
The exercise of power under the relevant section of the law can be applied to bail orders passed by the Sessions Court.
Limitations on Anticipatory Bail Duration
Anticipatory bail should ordinarily not be granted for an unlimited duration.
Limitations on Anticipatory Bail Duration
The Supreme Court has established that anticipatory bail should be granted for a limited period and that the accused should approach the regular court for bail.
Criteria for Cancellation of Bail
Cancellation of bail requires cogent and overwhelming circumstances.
Criteria for Cancellation of Bail
Factors such as interference with the justice process or potential evasion of justice justify the cancellation of bail.
